snippet.textDisplay:
I came from 2.0. The game has good and very-not-so-good bits and I'm afraid I have been more disappointed than actually enjoy it. On top of that, story and quest lines are confusing, NPCs disappear without any sense of understanding.

Environmental details are indeed the best part of the game. I liked interconnected maps and the level of exploration but disagree the game has tons of different weapons and variations, They only look different but in practice seem like a copy of a couple of weapons. Stats scaling is also weird. I ended up playing with only two swords, some times daggers, one spear, and a small shield and only because I wanted to have different runes in use depending on situations. I would probably stick to a single weapon.

Combat is far from smooth, is awful and one of the worst in games I played even including old titles, dual-wielding works somewhat strange and has an unnecessary delay. Character moves too much forward when attacking. Bosses are either pushovers or got some combos with artificial breaks-and-push-me-away mechanics impossible to defend/parry/dodge no matter what. Movesets and hero animation simply don't correspond to each another. From Combat-wise mechanics standpoint, devs hasn't demonstrated a real sense of what a good soulslikes game really is. There is also no sense of poise and posture in this game apart from parry and a gauge indicating that next kick would stun an enemy.

And lastly the game has performance issues with certain areas, it crashes, stutters even though settings were set on Low. Quests can bug--I had to repeat one area just because one of the NPC refused to continue the progress. I have no idea what happened. The game still has bugs and is literally a hub of bugs. I don't think devs are in control at all.

Sorry but the game was rather disappointing. I recommend the game but with cautions and always when someone asks between this game and anything else, I recommend "anything else".

snippet.textDisplay: Just played it in 2025 and it's amazing. Not sure how it was on launch but it does sooo many things right. I'm a huge souls guy, a fromsoft-sexual honestly, been addicted since demon souls. I enjoyed lotf2014 but this just blows it out of the water. The enemy variety and density isn't the best, and weapon movesets are only one per class. However, the world layout and interconnectivity is top notch, right up there with ds1 (well, sort of). It has DLCs that aren't p2p, you can replay bosses anytime. There are boss rush modes that unlock awards. There are armor tincts so any armor can be made into any color, items that drop from enemies who fall off ledges are still accessible - even if you reset the game and come back to the area later. The umbral thing with the lamp is great, at least I think so. The way magic works is better than any FS game and the spells are all useful to some degree. The best (but also the worst) part is there are no silly matchmaking restrictions. You can be max level and invade a level 1 and vice versa, same with PvP. However, the host is always gimped. My main is level 541 (current max) and I got invaded by a guy who killed me in 4 hits, yet I did shit all to him. I messaged him and he was level 52, so he got scaled to my level but it was too much. After testing with friends it seems to be some issues with that. That's my biggest complaint. Overall though its an awesome game. Totally worth the 50/60$ but maybe not full price. At least in 2025.

snippet.textDisplay:
I'm at the beginning of the game but I already have gripes with it.
When you start the game, you watch a 5-6 minutes long cutscene you don't understand, you throw away your lamp (I guess that's symbolizes how you revive in this game), spend way too much time in the clancky character creation window, you choose a class without knowing the game mechanics then read dozens of tooltips because the game gives every mechanic to you at the very beginning. There is no immersion at all.
How i would have fixed it:
Skip the obscure cutscene, tell the story through the game. Instead of watching some random character die, play as that character with midgame specs, using melee, ranged weapons and magic, so you get a feel for the combat. Optionally show us the Umbral world, but that can happen with the new character aswell, but not at the beginning of the game, because that messes up the pacing. And ditch the character creation segment. There is literally no reason to have such a detailed (and clancky) character creation segment for a character you won't see.
Even if everything else stayed the same, this would have elevated the game for me.

snippet.textDisplay: The first 30 minutes of this game feel BAD. I think the way it takes you into nightmare place or whatever is a mistake. And using the lantern is not fun. Then the game transforms the level and loses any immersion of where you are and it becomes a blend of vile and messy walls that all look the same. The combat felt average. snippet.textDisplay:
Pretty easy pass for me. I was utterly underwhelmed by the first LOTF, and this only looks marginally improved and not to the point I'd wanna give this a go, even at $40-50. The only thing I liked here were locations & level aesthetics and the giant Boss shown towards the end. The combat and flow still looks so off to me. Also not the biggest fan of the enemy variety from the bits of video I've seen and without something like the Souls games having a great story & lore as a backdrop for ruined kingdoms & castles & cursed or rotting creatures & humans, I'm just not feeling the appeal to dig into this game & world.

Some neat ideas, but the other world sounds cool but kinda annoying in practice for levels to double up with exploring, then re-exploring to not miss anything. Having enemies spawn more frequently there would absolutely become annoying for me and I dunno, seems more suit to a hack n slash rog game VS Soulslike. 

In a world where we have SO many of these kinds games, from the huge juggernaut titles of FromSoft themselves, to Nioh 1 & 2, Lies of P, Blasphemous, Wu Long, Jedi Survivor, Hollow Knight and many others. Just find it hard pressed to get excited with this one, even if things are improved, there's something missing to hook me.

The developers announced that they're doing another one, third time's a charm maybe?

snippet.textDisplay: Problem is I'm just so tired of "soulslike" games as it is. They all turn into a long methodical slog of meet new enemy>die>learn pattern>defeat enemy>meet new enemy>die>learn pattern>defeat enemy. Every enemy has zero artificial intelligence and use the same moves repeatedly. They have nothing to do with being "good" at the game or not, and everything to do with patience and trial and error. If they actually gave you a good story I might _care_ about going through the long methodical slog but they also seem to love trickling tiny bits of story to you over hours and hours of gameplay. The only thing that makes them worth putting time into is boss fights, and it really pisses you off when you spend so much time slogging through uninteresting enemies to find a boss fight that sucks.
snippet.textOriginal: Problem is I'm just so tired of "soulslike" games as it is. They all turn into a long methodical slog of meet new enemy>die>learn pattern>defeat enemy>meet new enemy>die>learn pattern>defeat enemy. Every enemy has zero artificial intelligence and use the same moves repeatedly. They have nothing to do with being "good" at the game or not, and everything to do with patience and trial and error. If they actually gave you a good story I might _care_ about going through the long methodical slog but they also seem to love trickling tiny bits of story to you over hours and hours of gameplay. The only thing that makes them worth putting time into is boss fights, and it really pisses you off when you spend so much time slogging through uninteresting enemies to find a boss fight that sucks.

snippet.textDisplay: For your comments on the jump mechanic, I understand why Lies of P and Lords used the classic way of jumping, in Elden Ring everything is fully open and in Legacy Dungeons there are usually high walls and such to prevent exploitation, whereas in the other games having a dedicated and controllable jump button makes them have to put in a lot more effort to adding barriers, closing sections and such.

snippet.textDisplay:
I have been having a blast with this game. Playing on console (PS5) and stutter was only an issue on quality mode. Changing to performance made a huge difference. Even looked much better in terms of detail, was odd but works well.

The multiplayer really is seamless and so simple to do! Just beckon a friend while visiting a shrine and hit the road. Me and my brother have been playing through the story together and it's tons of fun with a friend. I also play solo but the way they do multiplayer just hits different for a souls like game. It's a very welcome change. I find the characters to be more interesting than I originally expected. I found myself very interested in Pietas backstory in particular.
 I think this is a great way to bounce back for the series. I would definitely consider playing a sequel. They need to iron out some things but if they lean into the strengths of this game and further expand the lore, I can see myself playing for quite some time.
snippet.textOriginal:
I have been having a blast with this game. Playing on console (PS5) and stutter was only an issue on quality mode. Changing to performance made a huge difference. Even looked much better in terms of detail, was odd but works well.

The multiplayer really is seamless and so simple to do! Just beckon a friend while visiting a shrine and hit the road. Me and my brother have been playing through the story together and it's tons of fun with a friend. I also play solo but the way they do multiplayer just hits different for a souls like game. It's a very welcome change. I find the characters to be more interesting than I originally expected. I found myself very interested in Pietas backstory in particular.
 I think this is a great way to bounce back for the series. I would definitely consider playing a sequel. They need to iron out some things but if they lean into the strengths of this game and further expand the lore, I can see myself playing for quite some time.

snippet.textDisplay: I actually do like the dark souls jumping simply because that's how it really works if you want to runt and jump, especially considering the armor, which turns a seemingly shitty mechanic into a subtle piece of world building. With that being said, I in no way shape or form expect everyone to agree with me on that, including but not limited to you.

snippet.textDisplay: I just wanted to give a normal guys review on a pretty decent game that I purchased and that‚Äôs exactly what I‚Äôm doing here Lords of the fallen for $60 is OK it‚Äôs definitely no Elden ring it‚Äôs definitely no demon souls but what it is it does pretty well it‚Äôs going for a pretty generic, pretty safe souls like nothing new nothing special but it‚Äôs a good formula and it follows it very well. Graphics are pretty good combats really fun. The game is decently challenging it has amazing, customization options, and really cool armor, really really cool boss, designs and pretty in-depth animations for what you‚Äôre paying for but like I said earlier, if I had to compare it to a game like Elden Ring, it doesn‚Äôt even hold a candle, to a game like Elden ring but if you don‚Äôt go into this game with Elden Ring expectations. I think you could have a ton of fun long story short I would definitely recommend it for anyone that‚Äôs just looking for a new souls like

Let me say that I do like souls-game jump mechanics forced to be used for dashing and also low verticality.

Beside the fact that you are wearing heavy armors and keeping tons of weapons and items in your inventory, I think that limiting jumping makes it easier to create a map where you know they can't go out of bounds easily by default (instead of adding everywhere invisible walls)

snippet.textDisplay: It is still a  mess. They have released 8 patches which hasn't resulted in much significant change in the balance or optimization. The devs claim to be open to feedback but based on a Q&A they did it sounds like despite the copious amounts of negative feedback they have received they are really only interested in seeing their own vision through. All that aside many players are reporting a bug that wipes your stat points back to base level which results in them not being able to use any of the weapons they have and pretty much a useless character. I would not buy this right now, it is far from being ready for release despite it being out for 8 days. If you want to scratch that souls itch I recommend Lies of P.

snippet.textDisplay: I don't love the jumping mechanic or hate it I like it because its different but I can see why people don't like it and I would have fun either way but I am happy that they kept it because it added to the strategy of of positioning yourself durring a fight because you couldn't spam jump when you accidentally find yourself stuck in a corner in a fight its a bit of realism that I personally enjoy because lets be honest here I don't care how big and strong your muscles are gravity is the same for everyone and the more mass you have the harder it is to escape the pull of gravity and unless you are using magic it doesn't make sense to me how you could just spring off the ground with no build up of momentum I'm all for breaking the rules of physics with magic etc etc but when you have that ability with no lore to explain why it just breaks emersion for me. Liek why is my muscle bound fighter guy who has no magical powers able to just ignore gravity at will when ever he wants to it makes no sense even in a made up story where magic exists. but I'm ranting I'd be fine with either type of jumping but I am never gonna complain when a developer decides to make jumping more consistent with the basic fundamentals of gravity

snippet.textDisplay: The thing I don't understand about the majority of souls-likes in general is, how, despite the nuanced changes they make to the formula gameplay wise, how INCREDIBLY derivative they are in design. Like jesus, even the UI is nearly the exact same as Dark Souls.' They really don't feel like the games are 'inspired' by Dark Souls, it feels more like the devs said "Let's make royalty free dark souls."
snippet.textOriginal: The thing I don't understand about the majority of souls-likes in general is, how, despite the nuanced changes they make to the formula gameplay wise, how INCREDIBLY derivative they are in design. snippet.textDisplay:
Is it just me or is the souls "like" actually a souls "clone"? I never played any of those as gaming for me is a trauma cure, not a trauma constructor, but I've seen a ton of different souls games playthrough. 

But my point is, that it all seems it has the same exact UI, same exact HUD, same exact graphics, same exact gameplay, same exact sound design and for some reason the same exact font on everything.

Did the From software sell their formula to every other company, or why does all souls "like" seems like souls "clone"? For example the roguelikes seems very different and original in every instance. If you would show me any souls game, I would not be able to tell you if it's Dark Souls 3, The Lords Of The Fallen or Elden Ring as they look exactly the same.

snippet.textDisplay:
I personally wasnt a fan of jumping in elden ring. It was a sloppy addition imo. It looks bad and it hurt pvp. It's too floaty. We lost the cool jump attack animations from ds3 which were some of my favorites.

From a level design perspective, uts probably a good change, but i prefer being grounded in these games. Its restricting, sure, but i think it just works better. Maybe it's a weird example, but look at mass effect. There was a weight there that got lost in me: andromeda, and it hurt the franchsie imi. There's more to that story, but more people play me3 multiplayer than me:a multiplayer these days, im pretty sure.
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: When I first played Dark Souls, I always thought the jumping mechanic was a bit weird. Especially coming from more hack and slash and zelda games prior, jumping has always been a normal thing in games. Though, I'm guessing they removed a specific jump button in Dark Souls to be able to have another button to do something available on the controllers at the time. So I'm going to assume it was to fit functionality within the limitations of controllers, and then it just took off as a trend maybe?
snippet.textOriginal: When I first played Dark Souls, I always thought the jumping mechanic was a bit weird. Especially coming from more hack and slash and zelda games prior, jumping has always been a normal thing in games. Though, I'm guessing they removed a specific jump button in Dark Souls to be able to have another button to do something available on the controllers at the time. So I'm going to assume it was to fit functionality within the limitations of controllers, and then it just took off as a trend maybe?

snippet.textDisplay:
If you are planning to pick up the game because of the "seamless coop" DON'T. 
It's far from a seamless experience since only the host gets all the benefits of playing together. The joined player doesn't get items from chests, bodies or other predetermined locations or interaction. Further more the joined player only gets a fraction of the xp that the host gets (for example my friend, the host was level 20 with already some better gear and items while I was stuck on level 13 with only my starter equipment)... Really disappointed and in my opinion I wasted 60 euros on this game because I didn't really have any intentions of playing it alone in the first place.

snippet.textDisplay:
I'm on an 8 core amd, 3060ti, pretty damn decent - I'm getting solid 60 fps 1440p at all high settings and with cpu temps only around 80 degrees - 20 seconds of stutter loading the very first area, but apart from that has been super smooth, no crashing, lots of dying lol

I'm REALLY loving this game, it's scratching my darksouls itch so damn hard, the enemies are crazy aggressive and punishing, and it's a lot of fun exploring the 2 different worlds + umbral is low key creepy af - I love it, I love it, I love it, who knows if the combat will get much better, or the magic etc etc

it's the studio's first game and they've captured a darksouls feel REAALLLL nice imo I'm super happy to play it, and I hope they have good success with this so we get more like it - btw haven't been doing online play cos jeenine/steelovsky both said it's pretty broken, hopefully hexworks can get it fixed cos they got a reaaalllll nice game here

snippet.textDisplay:
Yeah im not gonna lie this game is quite possibly one of the worst takes on the souls formula. 

Bosses are pure rng with their attacks and punish you massively for even the slightest mistakes due to how the i-frames of your roll are lopsided ENTIRELY towards the beginning of the roll accompanied by insane levels of damage. 

This game is an AA game charging for AAA prices while delivering at the absolute most an AA experience.

It feels like they didnt take anything that DS3, bloodborne, and Elden Ring inproved upon, this game feels like if they wanted to do their own unique take on DS1/DS2. 


Genuinely the only way you're going to genuinely enjoy this is if you enjoyed those two, because DS3, Elden Ring, and Bloodborne all still absolutely fucking dunk on this game.

snippet.textDisplay:
I just played it for 8 hours straight and... man, am I doing something wrong? What's up with the difficulty here? I played every Souls game for.. far more than I'm willing to admit, but I'm really really bad at this one. I went up Pilgrim's Perch, and these Spike-Head things kept coming (at one time two of them at once), they are way to hard in my opinion. Plus, I keep falling down ledges, because everything is so narrow and this can happen very easily, especially in stressful combat situations. Jumping also sucks. I finally got to the Blacksmith, and finally could upgrade my weapon (now, after testing, the Spike-Head-Things aren't that big of a trouble anymore, but they still have a massive health pool). Next boss was easy, but I'm really concerned of what comes after that, since people said the game just gets harder. Not sure if I'm passing on this. On the bright side, I have absolutely no performance issues so far.
If you're wondering about how I'm 8 hours in and just got to the Blacksmith: As I first encountered the Spike-Heads, I was sure that I'm going the wrong way and this has to be for higher-level characters, so I wandered around for a lot of time, looking for another way until this was the only one left I could find.

Speaking as a PS5 player, i wouldn't recommend getting this game right now. It runs like trash, and is riddled with enough bugs that i question how it hasn't been taken off the market place like Cyberpunk was. 

-Numerous crashes
-Excessive Audio glitches
-PS2 era game menus
-Low FPS on "performance mode"
-NPCs not loading in
-Bosses AI glitching out
-Game menus stuck on infinite loading screens

And much MUCH more. CI Games this pathetic, ya'll should be embarrassed.

snippet.textDisplay:
"Even Elden Ring did that"

Not everybody is considering Elden Ring to be some standard too attain.
I actually thinks ER is way overhyped.
It's a nice game. With a lot of good things and a lot of flaws.
Too much flaws if you ask me.

My biggest complaint about Lords of the Fallen is the copycat flavor everywhere.
It's definitely too close too Dark Souls, and lacks personality and originality in the process.
It's to the point of a constant "deja vu" feedback.
Which was already a flaw of Dark Souls, coming out after Demon's Souls.(and that is why Bloodborne felt so fresh and interesting, because it's wasn't another Demon's Souls) 
It's 2023 now, so there should have tried a bit harder to do their own thing.

snippet.textDisplay:
The problem with these preview builds is that you cannot experience everything, so the review isn't complete.
For example, I'm hearing that the Coop gameplay is abysmal in this game, the guest/client cannot pick-up loot, gets only 30% of souls, cannot interact with NPCs, and his progress isn't saved.
I'm sure there's a lot of people who are only interested in games like these for the online experience with friends, so it would have been good to know these things beforehand.
snippet.textOriginal:
The problem with these preview builds is that you cannot experience everything, so the review isn't complete.
For example, I'm hearing that the Coop gameplay is abysmal in this game, the guest/client cannot pick-up loot, gets only 30% of souls, cannot interact with NPCs, and his progress isn't saved.
I'm sure there's a lot of people who are only interested in games like these for the online experience with friends, so it would have been good to know these things beforehand.

snippet.textDisplay:
IDK if anyone here has played "The-Medium" but I genuinely enjoyed that game for what It was and thought walking between the world of the living and the world of the dead was a cool concept that was greatly executed there. Seeing it here in Lords Of the Fallen, I was genuinely impressed because I've been saying for a while, I wish more games would follow that concept and build upon it. CI did a great job with this feature and made it even more interesting in my opinion than any other game I played before because of how interactive it is. Also, I'm bias to my souls-like. I'm not crazy far into the game, I'm about an hour or 2 in and so far, this review is pretty accurate as always with gameranx. I will say difficulty can be cranked a little for the tutorial bosses, IDK what later bosses hold but thats my take. Great video, love you guys. Enjoy lords of the fallen people. 


PS: Use your gameranx magic to convince CI to allow cross-play between xbox and PC (this is a musttttttttt) jk

snippet.textDisplay:
I'm starting to get really worried about reviews these days when they talk about performance. At the beginning of this video, the reviewer says that we can immediately see in his footage that there is a stutter that makes the game unplayable (contradicting the fact that he then continued to play and thoroughly enjoy the game). I've also seen other reviewers complain that their fps went down from 90 to 60 as a mark against performance and generally people just being pedantic about frame rates and resolutions.

I understand he's trying to provide a critique, as is the point of a review, but expressing those points so dramatically is just misleading. If a game can run at 30fps, even if it occasionally dips below that once or twice for a moment at some cinematic, graphically intense moments - that should not be labelled as unplayable. It's fine to bring it up and talk about it but the rhetoric around performance these days and the unwillingness to lose even a single frame has just made the whole conversation around performance useless to the average consumer. The word "unplayable" means nothing now but for a consumer that doesn't know any better, they will probably just be misled by that kind of rhetoric.
snippet.textOriginal:

At the beginning of this video, the reviewer says that we can immediately see in his footage that there is a stutter that makes the game unplayable (contradicting the fact that he then continued to play and thoroughly enjoy the game). I've also seen other reviewers complain that their fps went down from 90 to 60 as a mark against performance and generally people just being pedantic about frame rates and resolutions.

I understand he's trying to provide a critique, as is the point of a review, but expressing those points so dramatically is just misleading. If a game can run at 30fps, even if it occasionally dips below that once or twice for a moment at some cinematic, graphically intense moments - that should not be labelled as unplayable. It's fine to bring it up and talk about it but the rhetoric around performance these days and the unwillingness to lose even a single frame has just made the whole conversation around performance useless to the average consumer. The word "unplayable" means nothing now but for a consumer that doesn't know any better, they will probably just be misled by that kind of rhetoric.

snippet.textDisplay: Circling back to this video now that I have the game and I've played ~45 minutes. There's no stuttering AT ALL aside from when it loaded sharers upon first launch, everything has been smooth AF (and gorgeous too I might add). Running on a 3900x, 4090 at 3440x1440, 100hz. Great to see that this idiot Falcon firing off his mouth and likely causing tens of thousands of dollars in lost revenue for this studio because he flat out made shit up about Denuvo and said there were performance issues and STILL HAVE NOT PINNED A COMMENT to let people know that he's a fucking liar and that they shouldn't abandon ship. This video has been live for over 24 hours and no fixing his misinformation, it's disgraceful and he should straight up lose his job over this. I hope the devil studio sues his arrogant ass for slander. Seriously, nearly 8 million people are subscribed plus tons of people will search for this content and be served it as a recommended video and it's going to cost the undeserving devs literally tens of thousands of dollars. He should be ashamed

snippet.textDisplay: Been playing the game for a couple of hours and so far I like but it does have some issues. Now I know that this game just came out but I hope that these problems will be fix by devs soon. First thing are the visuals which isn't bad at all, but there's multiple times that the textures turn into mush. This also happens in cut scenes too which kinda break the mood. Then there's the constant freeze as you mentioned which to me makes the game feel kinda clunky. Lastly, this is probably my nitpick, is the character customization. Characters faces sometimes look untextured, when try clicking on certain tattoos are scars it doesn't seem to appear, and all around it feels tedious to make a character. This is probably my opinion though and I probably shouldn't be this harsh to a barley released game.
snippet.textOriginal: Been playing the game for a couple of hours and so far I like but it does have some issues. snippet.textDisplay:
It's me, I'm the one person that likes how jumping works in Dark Souls. all of the devs keep doing it because they love me

(specifically, I like Souls games being grounded and with normal realistic weapons; and a normal human can't really jump worth shit for exploration, so to me it makes sense to have awkward jumping. Though I'd be fine with classic 3D Zelda-style "jump automatically if you run off a ledge" jumping)

snippet.textDisplay: I havent played a Souls game since Dark Souls 2 (never played a Soulslike). I do have the Demons Souls remaster though for nostalgia, but havent gotten around to it. I am just purely burnt out on the genre after those first 3 games and just have no desire to play more of it. I watch this and it actually looks really fun. I'd love to explore the world and have fun in the RPG, but then remember bosses have just become annoying gimmicks in these games and this, like all the others, will be a pass. but this, more than any other Souls(like) game I've seen, piqued my interest, even if just for a minute.
snippet.textOriginal: I havent played a Souls game since Dark Souls 2 (never played a Soulslike). I do have the Demons Souls remaster though for nostalgia, but havent gotten around to it. I have tried three times to play this piece of crap, and I just can't get interested in it at all. I am a souls veteran but this looks like something that should be on a PS3. snippet.textDisplay: Word on multiplayer, it is not peer to peer like other souls games where everything is based on your own Internet. Its is entirely based on the world hosts Internet, which if they have not so good Internet can cause some pretty nasty latency/delay issues for everyone that isn't the host. So just keep that in mind when in multiplayer, not saying it as a deterrent just make sure you are aware connection issues may not even be your fault.
snippet.textOriginal: Word on multiplayer, it is not peer to peer like other souls games where everything is based on your own Internet. snippet.textDisplay:
Seems like this game has every single possible form of Unreal Engine stuttering (shader comp, traversal,  asset load/streaming). I'm sure that the whole "spirit realm" thing, aka having an entire world existing in parallel to regular in-game world is doing the game absolutely no favors when it comes to the streaming of assets. 

Theoretically, I could see that "sprirt world" gameplay feature basically doubling  the frequency of ever kind of stutter that the game sufferers from. Welp at least I can look forward to the Digital Foundry autopsy üòÖ

snippet.textDisplay:
This game has two worlds overlaid on each other that you can play on and look at at anytime with the lantern.  It‚Äôs actually similar to Ratchet and Clank: Rifts Apart in that way.  
  That means you have to have an SSD to even consider playing this game.  It is a current-gen only game.  
    Therefore it is Not unfortunate that it doesn‚Äôt work on PC‚Äôs with old hard drives,  as he says at 2:48. 
  It was designed for systems with SSDs like the PS5, etc.

snippet.textDisplay: Just something I wanted to add for PC players regarding performance issues: I watched/read some tests from other reviewers (most notably my go-to source: Gamestar, Germany's biggest PC gaming magazine), and they did mention that the PC version runs pretty well. They did occasionally get some stuttering after longer play sessions, but said that quickly restarting the game helps with that. Also, something I wanted to point out, apparently, the developers have already released 4 patches during the pre-release phase alone to quickly fix the performance issues. That being said, I highly doubt that the performance issues will last very long (if you experience any), considering how rapidly they started to bring out patches to keep the player base happy. It's actually really nice to see, especially considering that it seemingly is becoming the norm in today's gaming industry to release a half-baked game with a wobbly launch.
snippet.textOriginal: Just something I wanted to add for PC players regarding performance issues: I watched/read some tests from other reviewers (most notably my go-to source: Gamestar, Germany's biggest PC gaming magazine), and they did mention that the PC version runs pretty well. They did occasionally get some stuttering after longer play sessions, but said that quickly restarting the game helps with that. Also, something I wanted to point out, apparently, the developers have already released 4 patches during the pre-release phase alone to quickly fix the performance issues. That being said, I highly doubt that the performance issues will last very long (if you experience any), considering how rapidly they started to bring out patches to keep the player base happy. It's actually really nice to see, especially considering that it seemingly is becoming the norm in today's gaming industry to release a half-baked game with a wobbly launch.

snippet.textDisplay: I really don‚Äôt agree with gameranx‚Äôs take on the first  game and feel like it‚Äôs a bit of an over exaggeration. It was by no means a 10/10, but at the time of release it was very fun and solid. Graphically, it was a head of its time with its particle effects and attention to detail. The motion blur and camera angel could make you sick though lol. The gameplay was maybe shotty in some spaces, but depending on what class you played, it could feel very rewarding. Again, not a 10, maybe not even an 8 but I think the first game really warranted this reboot/sequel as it had a lot of fun ideas. Worth trying imo!
snippet.textOriginal: I really don‚Äôt agree with gameranx‚Äôs take on the first  game and feel like it‚Äôs a bit of an over exaggeration. It was by no means a 10/10, but at the time of release it was very fun and solid. Graphically, it was a head of its time with its particle effects and attention to detail. The motion blur and camera angel could make you sick though lol. The gameplay was maybe shotty in some spaces, but depending on what class you played, it could feel very rewarding. Again, not a 10, maybe not even an 8 but I think the first game really warranted this reboot/sequel as it had a lot of fun ideas. Worth trying imo!

snippet.textDisplay:
I think the reason jumping is so unintuitive in these games is to emphasize that they are not a combat tool.

If there was a button for jump, it would be logical to assume you could jump over attacks, but that clearly isn't something they wanted to balance combat around.
snippet.textOriginal:
I think the reason jumping is so unintuitive in these games is to emphasize that they are not a combat tool.

If there was a button for jump, it would be logical to assume you could jump over attacks, but that clearly isn't something they wanted to balance combat around.

snippet.textDisplay: ALERT!!! ANY GAME YOU PLAY ON PC CHECK TASK MANAGER EVERY TIME YOU LAUNCH ANY GAME AND FORCE CLOSE GAMBAR PRESENCE WRITER BEFORE YOU START PLAYING! That ruined my computer it ramps up your cpu for some reason and to a point where my pc was making grinding noises until I closed it then it ran at 30 percent usage! I have gamebar disabled on my pc and it still opens everytime I run elden ring or anything on gamepass and anyrhing that teiggers it which is most games I've ever played tbh genshin impact, tower of fantasy only game that doesn't run it is pgr for some reason! But I would get in a habit of checking your task manager it will save your pc overtime! Sorry so long! There is a way to delete the file but I didn't feel comfy doing so!

snippet.textDisplay:
Frankly, I'm more concerned with the lack of enemy variety than I am the performance issues. Performance issues can and will be patched but I highly doubt any enemies will be added in an update. Enemy variety is an important element for these kinds of games for a lot of reasons. It helps give areas unique identities and it gives the player a break from the monotony of fighting the same foes. 

Hopefully it doesn't end up impacting the game in a major way. Dark Souls 1 had 67 or so enemies and this game reportedly has around 40. Doesn't seem so bad until you consider that this game's map is around 3 times as large.
snippet.textOriginal:
Frankly, I'm more concerned with the lack of enemy variety than I am the performance issues. Performance issues can and will be patched but I highly doubt any enemies will be added in an update. Enemy variety is an important element for these kinds of games for a lot of reasons. It helps give areas unique identities and it gives the player a break from the monotony of fighting the same foes. 

Hopefully it doesn't end up impacting the game in a major way. Dark Souls 1 had 67 or so enemies and this game reportedly has around 40. Doesn't seem so bad until you consider that this game's map is around 3 times as large.

snippet.textDisplay: Funny enough, the original Lords of the Fallen was my first "souls" experience.  Elden Ring was my 2nd (that I can remember).  I really enjoyed the first one and (probably because I didn't play any of the actual Souls games) didn't understand any of the criticism to it.  This remake appears to be unrelated to the original in every way, except maybe the enemies and setting, but good none the less.  Thanks for the honest review, as always.
snippet.textOriginal: Funny enough, the original Lords of the Fallen was my first "souls" experience.  Elden Ring was my 2nd (that I can remember).  I really enjoyed the first one and (probably because I didn't play any of the actual Souls games) didn't understand any of the criticism to it. snippet.textDisplay: the pc version should never be the benchmark for either high fidelity or performance issues. it is very hard to release a pc game, and nowadays the expectation is to buy insanely expensive graphic cards and work with a very wide pool of options. on the other end you can boost pc versions to the high heavens if you know how and patches will be incoming. for me cyberpunk is the  best example: it looks awesome on current gen consoles but crazy on pc when running on a monster rig. but that¬¥s not the standard. same for last gen. good that they skipped the last gen for the dlc. for me it¬¥s more important that you have great worldbuilding, crunchy combat, cool story, a strong UI and smart enemies and bosses as well as a good art direction and soundscape
snippet.textOriginal: the pc version should never be the benchmark for either high fidelity or performance issues. it is very hard to release a pc game, and nowadays the expectation is to buy insanely expensive graphic cards and work with a very wide pool of options. on the other end you can boost pc versions to the high heavens if you know how and patches will be incoming. for me cyberpunk is the  best example: it looks awesome on current gen consoles but crazy on pc when running on a monster rig. but that¬¥s not the standard. same for last gen. good that they skipped the last gen for the dlc. for me it¬¥s more important that you have great worldbuilding, crunchy combat, cool story, a strong UI and smart enemies and bosses as well as a good art direction and soundscape

snippet.textDisplay:
I love Dark Souls because everything in this game is built around a philosophical idea. 
That is why everything in this game works, because everything works for this idea. 
Everything revolves around it. 
This is a complete allegory on the development and decline of human civilization and the world as such.
Looking at Lords of the Falen I don't see that.
I see kind of cool things that are just made to look cool. 
I don't see the idea behind it.
maybe I'm wrong.
But that's really the only thing I care about.
Is there an idea in LOTF? and how deep is it?
